title: Pocket-Tactics (Third Edition): Night Parade of the Yokai

description.text: This is an outdated (but still playable using Third Edition rules) version of Pocket-Tactics. For the new (and much improved) Fourth Edition sets and pieces, check out this collection. We'll be updating the new edition to include rules for all of the Third Edition units, so if you have printed them (or want to), check in for updates and eventually all of those pieces' rules will be available. We've set up a Patreon page for anyone who's interested in helping to fund us so we can keep making free and open sourced games like Pocket-Tactics, Wayfarer Tactics. and others, not to mention the growing catalog of gaming miniatures that you can use for whatever you want! (Psst... we take requests and commissions...) Enjoy! This set was inspired by the amazing (and comprehensive) work of fellow Thingiverser, Matthew Meyer (Osarusan: http://www.thingiverse.com/osarusan/about). Check out his book, The Night Parade of One Hundred Demons, and his new one, The Hour of Meeting Evil Spirits. http://matthewmeyer.net/ Big thanks to Jerome Brask of TimePortalGames for the awesome, laser-cut tiles! http://www.thingiverse.com/TimePortalGames/about ...and, Pocket-Tactics is now available in the Steam Workshops for Tabletop Simulator! Get the Night Parade expansion here: http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=400795768 https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=i1YF8dQfzWs

title: Support bracket for Y idler on ToM

description.text:
Unlike the X axis, the Y axis idler is supported on one end to the acrylic middle plate. This arrangement places a pretty good load on the acrylic and I noticed some flex as the Y axis would change direction. I designed the bracket to fit over the head of the Y axis idler bolt and attach to the two top screws of the rod cover.
Please note, this part is dimensioned for a stock ToM. My ToM Y axis rods a slightly longer than the body and make the body bow out. I've seen others comment on this so I know I'm not alone. 
Also, I'm not implying that this is a defect in MBIs design, the acrylic may be happy with this for years without problems.

Print the part and drill out the holes. The hole for the idler bolt is 9/32", work your way up to this so you don't change the location of the hole. The two rod cover bolt holes are 1/8"
To install just remove the two top rod cover screws, slide the part over the idler bolt head, run the screws back into the part. The screws are just long enough to work.

comments.text: It's not impossible to design one.  It is impossible to calibrate iron sights to work with the games.  The crosshairs on the screen will not line up with the iron sights.  We tried very hard, and could not do it.
comments.author: leo021

comments.text: Have you tried any games that incorporate motion-plus? Gut feeling says that would help over the traditional controller/games.
comments.author: Swift2568

comments.text: Motion plus won't help.  Shooting games use the camera in the nose of the wiimote.  The problem is the scaling algorithm that changes that camera data into coordinates for the screen crosshairs.  Intuitively we think of it like a laser beam from wiimote to screen, and assume the crosshairs should line up.  The old NES zapper worked like that, sensing only exactly the point on screen directly down the iron sights.  The wiimote camera is very different though.  It does not sense the screen at all.  The camera in the wiimote is picking up the IR LEDs in the sensor bar and using their orientation and the distance between them to calculate where the crosshair should be.  There are some scaling factors involved based on assumptions about screen size and player position that make it so that you can not calibrate iron sights for the wiimote.

title: 'Alien' Facehugger Containment Tank for an Insect or Other Small Nasty

description.text: I have a ghost praying mantis that needed a new place to live, so I recreated the facehugger containment tube from the first 'Alien' movie.  I looked at some photos to model it, but didn't go nuts trying to make it perfect.  I think it could work to house a variety of small animals, maybe scale it up, add some silicone caulking and put a fish in it?  The holes in the top work and printed ok, but honestly should be done away with entirely.  It adds a ton of time to the print and doesn't print all that well, I just did it cause I was impatient and didn't have any screen door material laying around.  Anyway... enjoy :)

I made this with pieces I had around, but you could totally scale the parts and use something else. I used the following:
  • 4" diameter acrylic tube, about 7" long
  • 4mm brass rod, cut to about 6 7/8" but just use the right length ya know?? I think it would look better with aluminum rod, but I didn't have any :/
  • Print all three parts, the bottom and top need support but not the rim. I printed at .2 layer height and it worked well.
  • The parts press-fit together pretty well for me, I gave them tolerance to do this. Your printer might be different so I can't guarenty it will be the same. If you are scared, just scale up the parts by a fraction of a percentage and glue it. But you're lame then.
  • Put some eco earth and some twings in there and catch a nasty thing to put inside

These are some of the mods I designed to accommodate my Shapeoko 2 electronics into a computer case I was no longer using. I still plan on adding an motherboard and such to it to have an all inclusive case for the host computer and CNC electronics. The case used is an InWin Maelstrom case with tool less design. The tray should work with just about any computer, but the cover may not unless your case covers are similar to mine. The top cover in the pictures is used for the Spindle Speed controller found @ Inventables. It is mostly pressure fitted in place but uses screws to apply more pressure to secure it into place. The bottom tray houses the TinyG. It has holes for a 120mm fan or my TinyG mount I made found here : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:672426. I included blank trays and a cover in case you needed to modify them for your own purposes. Let me know if you have questions, comments, suggestions, or concerns. Thanks =)

I printed everything @ .2 Layer height. Infill was around 35% I think. Maybe more, can't remember. Some holes took a little filing to get right as I didn't account for swell or squish when I took my measurements.

Counter-top Garden :D
( An easy to run, compact , uncomplicated Aquaponic system )
aka usues NO DIRT! With: a water pump, some aquarium hardware, a little bit of engineering, and the beautiful power of miracle grow.. the magic of aquaponics is in your hands, AND ON YOUR COUNTERTOPS! You will be able to grow almost anything you'll ever need in the kitchen- from Herbs to Peppers in this simple setup. This thing is aprox. 249.87mm x 154.07mm x 105.39mm

This thing is ready to print! For best quality print at 0.1 (or smaller if you can). Also it's recommended to do 35% infill OR LESS, really anything more is not needed.
Happy Printing To make this project you'll need:
  • PLNTR & components printed
  • A DC water pump, like this one-
    http://www.ebay.com/itm/310947764443
  • 8mm aquarium tubing (outer dia.)
  • Aquarium rocks
  • Miracle grow
    -T5 Florescent lamp (grow lamp)
    Optional: Grow lamp, hooked up underneath cabinets for extra growth :D
    • Instructions
    First off, print BOTH the PLNTR and its Auto-siphon Pipe, for they are crucial parts in the assembly. OK, take the DC water pump.
    With the 8mm aquarium tube, connect the bottom spout from the PLNTR to the 'in' port of the pump. Then, connect the 'out' port of the pump to one or both of the top spouts on the PLNTR. This is how the water will cycle- in through the bottom of the pump, out through the top. Next, take the Auto-siphon tube ( looks liek a little straw ). The short end of the tube will go into the hole, if it does not fit sand down the outer edges with sandpaper. The long end of he tube should be facing downward. Seal the connection with super glue. Now, take the Aquarium rocks and fill the basin to the brim, be careful not to break off the tube. Lastly, fill the container with the proper mixture of miracle grow and water. It should drain to the bottom. Keep filling until the pump can run without strain. Congrats! you've officially created your very own Aquaponic system!
    Now it's ready to plant whatever!! How the internals work..
    https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZHaiVhVZ3kM

I use the XYZ Da Vinci 1.0. I designed it in SketchUp and it doesn't seem to import into the XYZ software and slice cleanly. Instead, I used Silc3r and
exported to .gcode, edited the header to include the Da Vinci stuff, encoded into Base64 and saved as .3w. It printed perfectly. I'd imagine if you had Repetier or more open printer, the .stl would work as it should. Be gentle when clipping the supports from the slider. I used a small file to smooth the edges. I also used 10-32 nylon thumb screws to secure the bracket to the tank. Make sure you drill out the small holes with a bit close to 10-32. If the hole is too small, the tap will cause the layers to separate. Make sure you use ABS. Do not use PLA. PLA is a biodegradable carbon source for aquariums and will be consumed.

title: Syringe Extruder MK I for MendelMax 2.0

description.text: Syringe extruder for the MendelMax 2.0. Fits a range of syringe sizes to print a range of materials, including pastes, ceramics, hydrogels, silicone, and much more. Can use retraction to prevent oozing, and the endstop pauses the print upon material exhaustion allowing the syringe to be quickly changed and the print resumed. Made from 3D printed and laser / water jet cut parts, this syringe extruder can be mounted on the X-carriage or the frame of the MendelMax 2.0, or on the frame of the MendelMax 1.5 or any printer constructed with 2020 aluminium extrusions. Full BOM, 3D printed and laser cut models, assembly guide, firmware, and part drawings can be found at: https://github.com/LiamGilbertson/MM2SE https://www.dropbox.com/sh/y6ltoh3pgepo3vm/AAAvBzG1lgNL_WZn13ATKTGma?dl=0 http://www.instructables.com/id/Build-a-Syringe-Extruder-for-your-MendelMax-20/

This is the latest of a mounting base for an Arduino Mega.
Requires no screws or spacers to mount the Mega board.
Screw it to your widget (4 holes), then simply slide the board into the slot. Once it's fully inserted, a little pin snaps into a mounting hole in the board to retain it. To remove, simply push the tab down releasing the pin and slide your Mega back out. "Mega Base web.stl" has support for FDM printing built in to the slot in case your slicer has problems generating support for it. On my first print the little support segments popped easily and completely out with a little screwdriver. (version 1) For version 2 I added countersinks in the mounting holes so you can use either 3MM or #4-40 flat-head screws when mounting so the screw heads will not interfere with the underside when sliding the mega board into place. Version 3 is the most recent and I added a few more improvements, i.e. improved slots for better fits straight off the build plate and less interference with solder points on bottom of board. Added slots on the outside for adding a cover which will be forthcoming. edit to add: I just printed version 3 (with "simplify3d slicer), and happy to report that once the support was removed (pulled out easily like a zipper) the board fit the base and snapped in perfectly with absolutely no further cleaning (filing, deburring, etc.).

title: Leonard Nimoy Memorial Print.
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This item is strictly Non-Profit - strictly. Print it for yourself, give it to friends - it is a memorial, not a commercial item (although I'm flattered people want to sell it on ebay... ) but please, it's not to be sold and that's for not only the fact it has a licensed logo on it, but also for the fact it cheapens the ideal of why it was created. I can't really say too much, it is a very, very sad day.. I have watched Star Trek for about 32 years now... to my fellow Trekkies... I feel your pain. I was making a full size bust of Spock and I am just working on the face some more, but thought I would detatch the hand and make a small commemorative print out of it, I am printing mine at the moment at 0.2mm ,with No infil and no supports. RIP Leonard Nimoy :( :( :( "Scotty, One to Beam up" **Update 1/3/2015
Have uploaded a few variations, Carved, plain, just the logo and also a Hand without a base, which can still be printed without any supports. I made sure the thumb didn't go too far over that it would require support.

Unfortunately yes, I am aware of Just3DPrint/Steal selling this non-commerical print on Ebay.
It was marked non-commercial as it is a memorial, it was never intended to be made for profit. *Edit. Thank you Ebay, his page has been taken down!

title: Raptor 50 Titan RC heli electric conversion

description.text:
Motor mount and pinion adapter for electric conversion of Raptor 50 family of model helicopters.
Based on Rotary Weasel's design. Those parts were use as a test fit, aluminium machined parts were used in the final design due to needed strength.
If you dare using printed parts for actual conversion, it is advisable to weld the halves using ABS juice before using to gain needed strength.
Also, because ESC cover wast damaged during LiPo fire, new one was printed with an ear to mount it in place of header tank. Design fits Scorpion HK3-4020-910kv motor, or others with 25mm bolt spacing and 5mm shaft. I used Hobbywing Platinum 100A ESC with 6S LiPo battery, which fits perfectly inside the frame.
Powerplant is OEM setup taken from friend's crashed Gaui X5. I used Raptor 30 transmission, yielding ~1:9,6 gear ratio instead of stock 1:8,5, which with this setup should be suitable for 600mm, or even 620mm size blades. I made 8 flights already (hovering at 1750RPM and mild forward flight). With 6S 4900mAh LiPo battery, I've got 5 minutes of flight with 3.85V/cell after flight. I'm planning to recreate the models of printed parts in OpenSCAD and post them here as well. They might come in handy if you decide to make the thing on SLS printer (probably the only method that would be strong enough for the purpose). Many thanks for guys from Hackerspace Wrocław for help when designing the thing! DISCLAIMER: The printed parts were untested, therefore I cannot be held liable for any injury or property damage resulting from using objects based on this design. The user holds sole responsibility for operation of his/her model.

80mm Fan mounts so fans can be mounted on the 8mm smooth rods.  
I found that the more weight I added to the hot end the more inertia related issues I had. Low speed 80mm  (70mm between centers) fans blowing across the object being printed does the trick..

Japanese Puzzle Box, easier assembly. Modified for less precise printers. Widened grooves and more gap between moving surfaces. Moderate amount of filing and sanding still required. Less sturdy walls, 8% less material used, probably less printing time required compared to original.

Read my comment here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:571229.
Sadly, I could not make my printer accurate enough to print this model unmodified. I really wanted this one to work, so I carefully examined and then modified various measurements. I think the result is not very far from the original. Instead of the metal bars, M3 screws works ok. M3 x 13mm would fit precisely, found only M3 x 20 mm. The one for the drawer must be no longer than 15.5 mm (head included). Cut it to size. The screws make their own threads, no glue necessary, also make disassembling and reassembling possible. I embedded two coins into the bar, hoping that that would make it more "responsive", see picture. I am not sure it made any difference. I used slic3r, same settings for all parts: Layer height: 0.2, First layer height: 0.35, Perimeters: 1, Top solid layers: 4, Bottom solid layers: 2, Fill density: 20%.

remixed_from.author: RichRap
remixed_from.title: A bowden geared extruder for Rostock - based on Gregs

description.text:
Basically my interpretation of the Rostock Delta Printer. Most parts were redesigned in Freecad to suit my requirements better.  
Original parts printed with a Prusa i3.  
Flanged Motor and Idle ends so that adjustments can be made easily and accurately. The motor end frame makes an excellent mount for placing the heated bed on. Easy removal of the bed  allows for quick access to be electronics underneath.  
The wooden frame was needed to give the rigidity the printer needed to operate at all but the lowest speeds and ensure excellent print quality at higher speeds.   
The pivots use Jaws and 3mm or 5 mm aluminum rods which are forced (hammered)  into the jaws, no glue needed.  
Used Richraps geared extruder (Gregs)  printed a lower gear ratio so that Retraction speeds are greater but still has greater filament pushing power compared to the airtripper extruder which I never got working reliably.  
In the original design I had a slight play in the linear bearings, I tried different makes and combinations with smooth rods but could never get rid of the wobble, so printed some long carriages, 3 linear bearings per axis, and they are wobble free.

title: Heated Blower Fan Mounts for MendelMax 2.0

description.text:
Mounts for a blower fan attached to a heat gun with flexible ducting for heat setting curable 3D printable materials. This is a remix of JohnSL's Blower Fan for MendelMax 2.0 (Thing# 267212) which works really well at cooling PLA. I modified some of the supports so that it could be mounted on the bottom of the printer's X carriage to fit with my syringe extruder, and also made 2 different versions for long and short hotends and syringes. The short extruder mount is sized for a standard J-Head, and the long extruder mount is sized for an E3D. The mount is for a 51mm Blower Fan. I used this particular fan:
http://nz.rs-online.com/web/p/blowers/7878960/ , as this is rated for high temperature operation. The hose attachment is for 52mm flexible hosing for which I used high temperature silicon flexible ducting which can be fixed to the attachment with a hose clamp The heat gun mount is laser / water jet cut from aluminium, but this could be substituted for acrylic or similar as it does not touch the hot part of the heat gun. It is sized specifically for a Bosch GHG 660 heat gun as it has temperature controls :
http://www.bosch-professional.com/za/en/ghg-660-lcd-7699-ocs-p/ Remember to check the glass transition temperature of the material you used to print the mounts before turning the heat up!

Fix the blower fan to the blower fan mount and the hose attachment (if using) by threading long M3 screws through the hose attachment, blower fan, and blower fan mount in that order. Fasten with M3 nuts in the nut traps on the blower fan mount.  
Loosely fit a hose clamp around your flexible ducting, then slide it on to the hose attachment and tighten the clamp. Attach the fan mount to the X carriage of the printer with M3 bolts and nuts.  
Twist the front of the Bosch heat gun to remove the front guard. Attach the heat gun mount to the frame of the printer using M5 x 10 screws and M5 T nuts. Slot the heat gun in the hole of the heat gun mount so it sits flush, and fix with a zip tie looped through the small holes in the heat gun mount and around the handle of the heat gun. Loosely fit a host clamp around the open end of the flexible ducting, slide the ducting on to the end of the heat gun and tighten the clamp.  
Plug the fan into your printer's board and adjust fan settings to your preference.

comments.text: What materials are you printing with using this set up?
comments.author: cyclone

comments.text: Using this setup I printed the mounts using ABS which has a glass transition temperature of 105 degrees celcius. Even though the blower fan is ceramic I don't think it could go too far past this temperature, and my materials were setting well at 100 degrees anyway.

title: Sub 30$ 3D laser scanner Open harware/software project

description.text:
*update
French calibration available on github https://github.com/Sardau/Sardauscan update
http://www.instructables.com/id/Build-a-30-laser/
i've adden a instructable to explain how to build, calibrate and use the sardauscan. update: V0.0.0.4 out : (much) faster better stronger

description.header: Sardauscan is a open source Sub 30$ 3D laser scanner that you can easely print yourself.
Even 12$ if you already have a hercule HD twist.  I think we can say it's "the cheaper 3d scaner on earth"
description.text:
you just need a arduino nano, 1 to 4 line laser and a micro geared stepper (28BYJ-48)
(see instruction for BOM) no external power needed. just 2 free usb port on your pc : one for the webcam the other for the rest. UPDATE
I’m proud to announce you the release of the open source Software for the “cheapest 3d scanner on earth” the 30$ DIY Sardauscan. The software Is written in C# and allow you to compose your Scan task by drag and drop. Recommended Process is composed from these scan
“Scan” => “IrQ filter” => “merge laser” (if you use more than one laser) => “Build Mesh by interpolation “ => “Save STL”. But if you are not satisfied with the build-in processing task, or if you prefer use another heavy but powerful software to work with your point clouds like meslab or other, you can just “Scan” => “Save Ply” and import them in your preferred application. While the software come with a building support of the Sardauscan hardware, and usb camera. You can easely write your own Hardware proxy via plugins. You can event build your own task to insert in your scan process. Source Code : https://github.com/Sardau/Sardauscan real time scan video : https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TPb-gEVkBYo
postprocessing start @ 1:50, if you want to see the speed of post processing (smooth, mesh reconstruct, and stl generation ) French discussion : http://talk.smartfri.odns.fr/index.php?topic=368.0

Intro Seeing the price tag and limitations of commercial scanners I decided to challenge myself to build my own. It had to be cheaper and easy for anybody to build one using a 3D printer. Result The "Sardauscan" is a laser scanner, comparable to other professional laser scanners but for less than 20-30 times the price, and it has twice the number of lasers. My design principles were: · Keep it simple · Keep it low cost · Make it evolutive · Provide a complete solution The scanner is completely open source and open hardware: · The "Sardauscan" software is written in C# - the full source code is available. · You can write plugins for your own hardware or for your tasks. The software allows you to scan, smooth, build meshes and export to various formats. How does it work? The principle of a 3D laser scanner is simple. · A picture of the object is taken without any lasers firing · One laser is switched on and another picture is taken · Computing the difference between the two images, a laser trace (profile of the object) is obtained · By knowing the positions of the camera and laser you can derive the 3D coordinates of all the points on the profile · You do the same for all the lasers, turn the table and repeat the process until the table has made a full revolution And there you go, you have a complete point cloud representing your object. What do you need ? · A bunch of M3 (16 and 20 mm) · A bunch of M4 (12 and 20 mm) · 1x Arduino nano (Chinese copy, $4) http://www.befr.ebay.be/itm/NEW-Nano-V3-0-ATmega32... · 1x Chinese Stepper Motor (28BYJ-48) and controller (ULN2003) (5$) http://www.befr.ebay.be/itm/Uln2003-Stepper-Motor... · 1-4x Line laser 5v ($2.5$ piece) http://www.befr.ebay.be/itm/251688838898?ssPageNa... · 1x Hercule HD Twist ($15) http://www.befr.ebay.be/itm/Hercules-HD-Twist-5-0... · 20x20 profile (can be printed : there are plenty of STLs on the net) · optional 3x 4mm roller ($0.3 piece) (624 bearings Total: from $26.5 (1 laser) to $35 (4 lasers) About the 2020 lengths: this is not really important. The only constraint is to have the camera seeing the whole table. For example, here are the lengths I used for my build: · 2 x 140mm · 1 x 120mm · 1 x 250mm What to print All the STL files can be found on Thingiverse: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:702470 · 1 x arm_left.stl · 1x box.stl · 1x box_door.stl · 1x box_arduino_clamp.stl · 1x arm_right.stl · 1x CORNER.stl · 1x MOTOR_MOUNT.stl · 1 to 4 x laser_holder.stl · 1X Camera_HOLDER_LOWER_PART.stl · 1x Camera_HOLDER_UPPER_PART.stl · 1x center_axe_MINIMAL.stl OR 1x table_AXLE.stl (OPTIONAL) · 3x roller_baseV2.stl · you can print 12x M4_tslot_nut.stl if you use a 20x20 profile and you don't have any Remarks: · The 2020 profiles are just here for ease of use. You can use whatever you have: wood, metal, … · If you want to use another camera, you will need to adapt “Camera_HOLDER_UPPER_PART” to match it · The bearing are optional. They are only necessary if you want to scan heavy objects or don't have a perfectly flat table · The build is simple, just look at the pictures. You can't do it wrong · Put the motor at the center, place the 3 profiles around and screw them. Place the corner, screw, put the arms, screw, … · There is a hole for each screw, you can’t get it wrong. · For the wiring, please refer to the diagram. Firmware At this point all you need to complete the hardware part is to upload the firmware to the Arduino. You will need the Arduino IDE or another sketch editor. The firmware (a regular Arduino sketch) is available at: https://github.com/Sardau/Sardauscan You will also need to install the AccelStepper library in order to compile it: https://github.com/adafruit/AccelStepper · Edit configuration.h to match your wiring. · Upload it to your Arduino Now that the hardware is ready, test it! · Connect to your Arduino with your IDE · Type “Sardauscan” – the Arduino should answer “yes” · Try the stepper: type “T R 100” – your table should turn 100 steps · Try the laser: type “L 0 1” for the first (0) laser to fire (1) – the first laser should light up If something doesn’t work, check your wiring and configuration.h – it should match. Software and Calibration To install the Sardauscan software, go to github (see link above) and download the latest binary version. Extract it and launch the executable. In the main interface, you will see 3 red icons – one for the table, one for the lasers and one for the camera. Click on them to connect to the hardware (right click to disconnect). If you use the standard Sardauscan firmware the table and the laser switches are linked. Now that the hardware is ready and the software connects to it, here comes the tricky part: calibration. The calibration takes 3 steps: · A manual calibration · The build dimension · The "Adjust" correction Be careful during the calibration: the result quality directly depends on it. To calibrate: · Click the target icon and the ‘Physical’ button. · Move your camera so that the vertical in the preview window crosses the exact center of the table. · Click on the center of the table in the preview window. The lines will help you align the calibration object. · Place the calibration object (see STL on Thingiverse) on the table, flat area facing the camera – use the horizontal line for help. · Click on the first laser icon on top to light up the first laser. Align the laser line to the vertical line in the preview window. · Repeat for all your lasers. Build dimension: · Click on the “build dimension” button and enter your build dimension. Adjust: · As a perfect calibration is difficult to achieve, especially with a higher number of lasers, the correction step will help you correct the previous errors. · Place your calibration object on the center of the table and click “quick scan”. · When the scan is completed you will see a top view of it. Each color corresponds to a different laser. · The goal is to superimpose as best as possible the different laser scans: select a laser in the combo box and rotate (left mouse button), scale (middle mouse button) and pan (right mouse button) the scan. Congratulations , your calibration is done! Dafuq is this interface ? To be evolutive the software is designed around tasks and processes. When you open the program you will see to the left a list of available tasks – you can drag them to the process list on the right then press the ‘Play’ icon at the bottom. Here is a non-exhaustive list of the available tasks: · Scan: scan an object · Grab Pictures: take pictures of the object for use in a photogrammetry program · Filter IQR: remove noise from the data with an interquartile range filter · Filter median: remove noise from the data with a median filter · Angle: merge laser scan by angle – smooth the scan and filter noise · Bezier: smooth the data by fitting a Bezier curve · Surface: smooth the data with a Laplace surface smooth · Save ply: save a PLY file to use with MeshLab or any other point cloud software · Save stl: save the STL file Developer Corner : Evolution ? Own hardware ? Plugins ? As mentionned the software is not linked to the Sardauscan build – it is made to be evolutive. You can do almost whatever you want with plugins. You have a magical algorithm? Do a plugin for it ! You have a custom image acquisition hardware ? Do a plugin ! You want to use your own hardware firmware for the table or the laser ? Do a plugin ! You can look at the github repository, there are some plugins samples. It is really simple to code. To use the plugin, just copy then in the "plugin" subdirectory. Happy scanning !

comments.text:
The arduino is used to control the stepper motor that turns the table and to turn the lasers on and off, via commands from the PC.
So the software on the PC does the coordination of everything. It's not a standalone scanner.

description.text: 2-part holder for rigging an 80mm fan to blow across your Panavise clamp while soldering. Just needs a suitable fan and 3x fan mounting screws
Printed at 0.24mm layer height, 20% infill, no support or special features really needed.

This is InfinityONE, a 3d printable Octocopter.
    • What you get?
    • Have a look here:
    http://youtu.be/5XXBqkA6mS8 What you need to build one yourself?
  • Printed parts (I used PLA, 38% infill)
  • 2x Carbon tubes 330mm
  • 2x Carbon tubes 220mm
  • 46x 40mm M3 screws with self-locking-nuts
  • 8x Motors and Props (I use MK2832-35, Graupner E Prop 10x5)
  • 8x ESCs (I use Turnigy Plush 12A)
  • Flight controller (Design optimized for NAZAm, I use my own FC)
  • Battery
  • RC Remote
  • everything I forgot
  • spare parts..
    • How to build?

  • It should be quite obvious. To know how the parts and the carbon tubes fit, have a look at the youtube video linked above!
    If you need any help, contact me!

    • You want to support me?

  • As I am a student with no income, I would be happy if you support my projects! You can find the paypal button on my youtube channel!

comments.text:
Hello, I was reviewing your "What to get" and I didn't see the Motor type. What type of motors did you use?
Also having dual counter rotating props increases stability but at what cost to the battery usage? What type of battery did you use and how long will is stay in the air?
comments.author: DPierce

comments.text:
Hi there,
I use eight MK2835 from mikrokopter.
The upper four motors are counter-clockwise rotating, the others clockwise rotating so in total it's a counter-coaxial-setup. I haven't noticed any difference to a flat configuration. But this is likely to be caused by the "small" propellers with 10". For myself, I wouldn't run for larger props on multirotors. Everything above 13" isn't best for use in small, lightweight multirotors!

description.text: A simple support bracket to use to suspend your filament reels underneath a shelf.

Just source a suitable metal spindle and print to interference fit - I used an old support leg for a fibreglass bathtub! STL is for a 19mm diameter spindle, or download the OpenSCAD file and tailor with a simple variable change. Suitable for 200mm diameter reels.  
Print with a suitable strengthy infill, I would recommend 20%+ infill with a rectilinear or hexagonal pattern.

remixed_from.title: Sleeve Case for Raspberry Pi B+

description.text:
Raspberry box based on this design: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:604915 (Sleeve Case for Raspberry Pi B+) -> Thanks Walter!!
I just added a case for a 2.5 inches hard disk with some spare space for the conversor from SATA to USB. I simply took an external 2.5 HDD and take it away from the case, with its conversor.
You can see the leds light through the case, probably with most of the colors (that's a feature of the creator of that design, of course)
WARNING: This is a work in progress, meaning:
  • There are no connectors covers. Actually I don't see them very useful, since the initial design of the box doesn't fully cover them. And it doesn't make much sense a cover for the usb connector since each hard disk has a different position and type. Depending in your box you might even have the chance to reuse the cover.
  • It fits VERY tight, but in my case, with my CALIBRATION and some file refine, raspberry and HDD fitted fine (but I didn't have to take the disk from the case yet :-). Perharps a 102-103% scaling when printing with Cura might help (at least that was the advice of another user about the original design of the box)
    • It has 4 small sphere legs, so there can be some air flow.

Position: The hole of the micro sd should be on the heat bed.
Platform adhesion type: Brim (I recommend a big adhesion surface, because it is tall and it has a small base) You can see a picture of the adhesion surface I used.
Support: I didn't use it. The legs are spheres, so no support should be required.

author: tealid

description.text:
A bolt shaped pencil case
After spending the weekend building and testing my new MK6 extruder, I had seen quite a few of these and needed to exorcize thoughts of them rolling across the floor.
If you don't have an MK6, save up for one - they're fantastic!

Print 2 @ ThreadedTube.stl
Print 1 @ BoltHead.stl
Print 1 @ Nut.stl Don't print OneThread.stl, this is for use in OpenSCAD. Screw one tube into the head (blocking off the Hex slot with the blanked end of the tube) and screw the nut half onto the open end of the other tube. Glue these in place (or leave them, for a 4 part pencil case). I printed the first threaded tube and found the sides of the thread a little too shallow causing too much overhang. I have adjusted the slope and regenerated the STL files. Note, the Nut and Bolt Head are now threaded. I have now printed these revised versions so I have uploaded an image of the finished Bolt. I've uploaded all the files, I did need to adjust my feed rate down to stop the overhang strings (1.8) and I reduced the fill to 20% for the nut and the bolt head. Oh, my daughter insisted on blue, maybe one day, I'll have a black one of my own, I may even spray the nut silver, when I've got another 12 hours...

comments.text: To those having trouble with the tube not fitting in the head, just scale the head up about 2%. Worked great for me.

title: Prusa Air 2 X carriage - Micron direct drive extruder

description.text:
Got asked by a friend to see if i could work something out to fit the Micron extruder on a Prusa Air 2 Have taken my earlier X carriage design http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:154258 and re designed the top carriage plate to accommodate the micron extruder and still maintained the standard 2 holed spacing for other extruders ( Gregs wades etc)
This is concept Rev 1 and seems to work great. Although with the fan at the front it is difficult to see what is being printed and next revision will attempt to relocate the fan.
The micron direct drive ( geared stepper) and hot end is such a great piece of engineering it just had to fit somehow. The compromise is that the X axis only has 150mm of usable travel but that is a small price to pay , On the prusa air 2 using this extruder increases the build height to 125 so effectively what you loose on the X axis, you gain on build height.
If you like this ....hit the button Update March 1st >> Rev 2 Added a duct so the fan can be mounted to the side under the stepper motor. Much better view of the print during printing. Fan duct contains an M4 nut trap that is aligned with the adapter bracket hold down bolt

description.text: a Dragon KeyChain I made as a test print for "Fine" settings on the Flashforge Ceator Pro with no special settings. Turned out ok; there is no text on the uploaded version.
Started with a 2D image, extruded to 3D, added the hole and print.
Hand painted with plastic ink..

XT60 is by far my favorite lipo connector. The single issue I have with the connector is that I have not found a female XT60 connector that can be be mounted to something. I do not like having battery leads dangling out of my multicopters. I want the connectors to be mounted properly on the frame. The physical shape of the XT60-connector makes it difficult to make a good holder for it. There is next to nothing to hold on to to prevent the connector from being pulled out together with the battery contact. Since I have not found any holder that I like I have made one myself. My design is for a compact holder that actually manages to provide a steady grip by utilizing the only gripable surface available on the connector: the square cuts on the sides at the bottom of the connector. The holder should be printed with a relatively high infill so that it does not collapse when the screws are tightened. 75-80% should be fine. If you want to keep the weight down as much as possible, you only use the upper part of the holder. This makes it possible to save a few mm of screw on each side and the lower part itself. Using both the upper and lower part will provide an even firmer hold on the connector. If you scale the mount to 65% of the original, it will fit XT30 connectors. M2 screws should fit the downscaled holes. irun4fundotca has been kind enough to publish pictures of his scaled mount here:
http://www.thingiverse.com/make:134242

My bedroom was not getting hot air, I felt a warm spot on the floor and realized that the carpet was covering the vent escape. I cut a hole in the carpet and was left with a square vent with no cover.
I decided to fabricate one. It worked like a charm. Printed in 3 parts to fit a smaller printer.
Print the two end pieces and insert the number of center pieces as needed. Screw in to carpet or drywall. Should work with standard imperial screws.

NO, this is not Starship Enterprise even though It looks like. It is my interpretation of a 3d Scanner. With a few additionally parts, an android phone has all the capabilities to help you
3D scanning an item of interest.
Just follow the instructions!
Highlights about this scanners are:
  • small printing time, only the disk takes little more time
  • No microcontroller and firmware needed, only laser and motor
    • The video of the owl can be found at
    https://youtu.be/3iBqB1-8d1Y
    Another one of "Adolf the duck" is
    http://youtu.be/lmRgxYoPE90 I would really appreciate if you posted some fotos and some scan results!

PartList:
  • All the STL Files above once but 3dscanner_base two times
  • An Android Phone or Tablet
  • A red line laser like http://www.ebay.de/itm/281562839777
  • A small rotating Motor (only 3RPM) like this http://www.ebay.de/itm/261549739071 . A Microwave motor like http://www.ebay.de/itm/261301609520 is probably also fine.
  • 2 Aluminium square profile rods 10mm square - about 200mm and 300 mm length should be sufficient.
  • 2 Aluminium round rods Diameter 8mm X 100 mm
  • 2 M3x10 screws +_ 2 M3 nuts for inserting into the base
  • A rubberband to mount the android phone
    • Assembly/Setup
  • Print the parts
  • prepare the rods
  • insert the m3 screws and nuts into the base
  • mount the motor into the motor house
  • put everything together
  • connect the laser and the motor electrically. I used a 12V power adapter and an LM7805 to supplpy the laser
  • adjust the laser(1. adjust lens for minimal laser line thickness, 2 adjust laser to be exactly vertical, 3.) adjust laser to point exactly to center of dish)
  • Get Android app "scan3doid" from the Google Playstore (make sure to use at least 1.3, older versions are quite unstable)
  • Mount the Android Device to the phone holder
  • Finish with the instructions in the Android App
    • Some hints for succesful 3D scanning
  • First trial is not always the best. Retry with different settings to improve the result.
  • Care for a good setup. What the laser does not touch, and the camera does not see, will not be translated to the STL File
    • Happy 3D scanning

comments.text:
Scan3Doid is one option to create a 3D scan from your thing. It is basically taking a video from the turntable.
Android has perfect capabilities to taking videos :)
With the app you basically have to set some parameters manually, like start and stop time, lower in the video.
Other parameters are lower limit, upper limit, output dimensions.(There is no calibration)
Finally you press the "Process Video button"
Personally I can state, that I did have success with Scan3Doid. It was cheaper than the motor,
but maybe you find a better option.

This is a remix of Loubie's beautiful dragon sculpture, Adalinda: The Singing Serpent (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:246198). Loubie had added a channel through the print so it would look like she's singing. Taking that, I edited the print to include a reservoir to hold a 1" incense cone. Simply light up your incense, get a good coal going, and drop Adalinda on top. Enjoy! Note: NEVER leave incense burning unattended. You'll need to put some aluminum foil, or the entire print into an incense bowl to prevent the incense from burning through your table. Additionally, some types of incense can leave a residue on the inside track of the air channel (like you'd get in your chimney in your house). If you start noticing a strange smell coming from her, or visibly notice buildup of soot and such inside the channel you should attempt to clean it as best as possible to prevent it from accidentally igniting. The chances of this are very slim, but it is posted here simply as a warning.

From the original instructions:  
"You will need to use lots of cooling when printing her with PLA. With ABS, an enclosed environment is preferred as too much cooling will cause the model to crack  
You need to ensure your filament is measured as precisely as it can be (so your flowrate is correct) as the model will show up excess material really easily and it will spoil the clarity of the print."  
Also, this print can be scaled UP as much as you want, but do not scale it DOWN.  The reservoir is just large enough at this size to hold the 1" incense cone.  Any smaller and you'll be running into problems.  This model was scaled down from the original to fit on a tiny build platform, so maximize her!

comments.text: I've seen some incense work better than others, but it's been a while since I've lit one up to remember the brand I was using.  At the base of the sculpture you should see a little upside down U in her belly where the incense cone is visible when it's sitting flat.  That allows air-flow into the reservoir to keep the cone lit.  Make sure that isn't obstructed.  You might need to file it open a little more to increase the air-flow if you're still having issues.  Sorry to hear it's not working out for you.  I'll see about adding some additional feeding lines for air into the cone if you continue to have problems.

title: Spice Rack and Knick Knacks #CountertopChallenge
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This Spice Rack and Knick Knack drawer can be stacked AS HIGH and AS WIDE as you want. It is perfect for the every day cook to professional chef. This is part of the #CountertopChallenge of 2015. Features:

  • Interlocking shelves that offer a tongue and groove mechanism, each with their own nail hole in the back to hang. Make a H, L, or simply a square. Your choice.

  • Can be scaled to any size to work with any Makerbot. The original size is about 4x4 in.

  • Each drawer features a pinch handle to pull out, a rubber band groove that will offer a seal, and a pour path to help pour the spices (or nuts and bolts) out. The front has a label groove the height of a standard rule line of notebook paper.

  • End and top plate for a smooth look.
    • Updated 2/28/15- Printed it at half scale (about 3 hours), it looks and works well. I got rid of the rail system to insert the drawer into the shelf, it now operates a little more smooth and you gain a little more space for spices.

Printed well in PLA. Simply slide each shelf together into the tongue and groove mechanism. Secure the end drawers with nails/or screws to the wall (or set it on your counter). A rubber band around the frame of the drawer offers a tighter seal to keep your spices fresh.

This is a miniature model of cubesat I made for my SPace EXploration research group at RIT. The model can be screwed together to make just a mechanical model or it can be assembled with electronics inside. I have included all the design files for everyones editing pleasure! I do ask that if you use some of my designs elsewhere, mention me and this project. Also please note, this model has no dimensional accuracy's to the real thing other than its overall dimensions, it is entirely made from scratch and my imagination. Here is a video of it in action: https://youtu.be/k6n3DKMDLpE

• Trim both leads of each LED to about 4mm.
  • Trim one side of each resistor to the same length of the led’s leads.
  • Solder the short end of a resistor to the cathode (flat part) of the led; do this for all led’s.
  • Solder a short piece (50 - 60mm) of insulated wire to the other end of each led.
  • Place each LED into the holes form the outside of the cube.
  • Bend the cathode lead (the one with the resistor) of the each led flat against the plastic.
  • Rotate the led’s so the resistors are well situated and not touching other led’s.
  • Solder the long ends of each resistor to each other and attach another short wire to it. Don’t let the
    soldering irons tip touch the plastic.
  • Carefully pull/push the led assembly out of their holes. Use the end of a pencil if needed.
  • Now place the led assembly back into the holes from the inside.
  • Align the resistors and their leads so they do not touch. Use a small amount of glue if needed.
  • Push the other lead of the center led flat against the plastic and lightly push on it with a pencil so it is as
    flat as possible. Be sure no wires are touching.
  • Solder a piece of the leftover leads to the positive terminal of the battery holder (The lead next to the
    notch in the plastic). Carefully bend the lead flat against the plastic. Note: if the lead breaks off, re-
    solder it to any part of that metal.
  • Lightly glue the battery holder to the back cover. There is a recess in the middle. Be sure the side with
    the leads is facing the other hole (for the switch).
  • Put the switch in the hole and solder the wire from the battery to the middle lead of the switch.
  • Lightly glue the switch in place. Be aware of the travel of the switch.
  • OPTION 1: If you are assembling the cube to be a flashlight, solder the five pieces of wire coming from
    the leds together and to one of the leads on the switch. Trim the leads to be as short as possible.
  • Solder the remaining ground wire to the other lead of the battery.
  • Toggle the switch a few times to verify proper operation, troubleshoot as necessary.
  • Option 2: If you are assembling the cube to be animated solder pin 8 of the PIC to the ground terminal
    of the battery using a spare piece of wire or a scrap lead. Note: it may help to first lightly glue the PIC to
    the back of the battery case.
  • Solder pin 1 of the PIC to one of the outer pins on the switch with a piece of wire.
  • Solder the remaining pins to their individual leds In the following order:
    LED1—PIN7, LED2—PIN6, LED3—PIN5, LED4—PIN3, LED5—PIN2. Note: pin 4 is skipped.
  • Solder the remaining ground wire to the ground lead of the battery.
  • Toggle the switch a few times to verify proper operation, troubleshoot as necessary.
  • Final Assembly: Verify proper operation before continuing.
  • Secure all wires so no shorts occur. Use glue if needed.
  • Install a battery in the holder.
  • Push the two halves of the cube together and be sure no wires get stuck. Note: the assembly is a tight fit
    so it may take some force.
  • Screw all screws half way and verify operation again, troubleshooting as needed.
  • Screw the screws in all the way and verify operation yet again, troubleshooting as needed.
  • Attach a key ring to the hole on the bottom and the cubesat key ring is complete!

description.text: Just the raw genome data that has been extracted from my DNA so far.

Reference/Source: This data file generated by 23andMe at: Fri Apr 5 14:16:53 2013 Below is a text version of your data. Fields are TAB-separated Each line corresponds to a single SNP. For each SNP, we provide its identifier (an rsid or an internal id), its location on the reference human genome, and the genotype call oriented with respect to the plus strand on the human reference sequence. We are using reference human assembly build 37 (also known as Annotation Release 104). Note that it is possible that data downloaded at different times may be different due to ongoing improvements in our ability to call genotypes. More information about these changes can be found at: https://www.23andme.com/you/download/revisions/ More information on reference human assembly build 37 (aka Annotation Release 104): http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/mapview/map_search.cgi?taxid=9606 Data Sample: rsid chromosome position genotype rs4477212 1 82154 AA rs4757064 11 12909146 AA rs2378956 14 32509543 GT rs16952589 16 47174275 AA rs7207392 17 76721938 AA

Only managed to make one so far and with a lot of help from my parents. It's been a few decades since this code was compiled and it may be missing some dependencies on modern platforms.  
Heated bed optional.

title: Adjustable Tablet Holder Stock DJI Phantom Controller Clamp V2

description.text:
This is an update to my previous design: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:512916. See the old version for more construction details.
The old design was my first on my printer and had some flaws, one of which were all the rounded corners, an old habit from my work.
It made warping of ABS parts more likely.
Some dimensions were modified to handle small tablets and big phones. Holes were opened to allow faster printing and less drill bit cleanup. You need to print two clamps and one slider. The rods are #8-32, as well as the nuts. Using washers might also be a good idea.
Again, see the older version for more construction detail. There is no need to crank down on your tablet!
just snug is good. Do not risk cracking something!
Use some thin foam in the channels, like shoe inserts, 1/8" thick, if you want. I don't.

description.text:
An indispensable accessory for our 3D functional printer and integrated into the whole.
Adaptar un controlador barato made in PRC es de esas cosas indispensables.
Bulldog

Calibrate Z axe with setting perfect distance from top for all tree towers.
Three steps:
  • Set your rod length (by measuring rods)
  • Change diagonal (horizontal) length until print is not neater convex nor concave (useful tips on http://letsmakerobots.com/content/kossel-mini-calibration)
  • Change screw distancers of each tower (that touch endstops) until you get same line width on all sides
In 2002 I hiked Quandary Peak in Colorado.  It was the first time I had hiked a 14er and I created this memento as a remembrance of that day.

I created a base separate in case someone wanted to print it without the base and to allow for dual printing. I also created one with the description and height etched into the side and one without so others could create a remix with the dates that they climbed the same peak.
Approximate time to print at 3 inches by 1.5 inches was 2.5 hours at .15 mm and 15% fill.

description.text:
I really like the MaskedRetriever's printed planetary gears - but I wanted it to be able to stay together without the need for a rubber band, glue, etc.
Thus, I fired up OpenSCAD and whipped this up.  Just print the base, the crown, and planets from the original printed planetary gears (linked above) and then slide them into the holder.
You'll need the original files if you want to tinker with my OpenSCAD file.  Otherwise, if you just wanna get printing, I've included the STL as well.

title: Monster Bites Phone (Stand, dock, phone nom nom)

description.text: A extraordinary beautiful phone stand that can also be used as a charge station/dock. You can of course also use just as a cool decoration. A phone charge cable can be put into it from the back. There is a adapter that holds it and fits into the slot of the head. The teeth are printed separately and put into the teeth flesh slot. The tongue can be used as a cap. You can choose from different teeth and adapter that fit your smartphone. Check out the textured version on Sketchfab: https://sketchfab.com/models/3d346cad931648dfa64c6b8bc9fdfb46

Print requires support (mainly for the ears) For using it as a phone stand:
Choose the teeth that fit your smartphone, note that there is already some tolerance and it is not really a problem when it has 1 or 2 mm space. The teeth hold pretty good without glue but it is still better to glue them on. Following gaps are available
  • 7.6mm (like for iPhone5)
  • 9mm (like iPhone 4)
  • 7.2mm (like iPod 4th gen)
  • 6.2mm (like iPod 5th gen)
  • 10 mm
  • 12 mm
    • There are also 2 versions of the tongue in case your need the thinner one: BiteMonster-Tongue-7.6mmThickness-fin and BiteMonster-Tongue-6.1mmThickness-fin For also using it as a charge station:
    The adapter comes as a perfect fitting Apple adapter (26 x 6 x 9mm):
  • BiteMonster-Adapter-Apple--fin.stl
    http://i.imgur.com/1lwNUPxl.jpg
    • And a universal version (for the usual cable comes out of the back):
  • BiteMonster-Adapter-Universal-part1-fin.stl
  • BiteMonster-Adapter-Universal-part2-FORca7mm-fin.stl ...

    http://i.imgur.com/tFNML2Vl.jpg
    • But you can also make your own perfect fitting one. I included the .obj files for all the adapter versions. Just make sure then to also include some tolerance. They are in the extras.zip There is also a version for a adapter where the cable comes out at the side:
  • BiteMonster-Adapter-CableSide-fin.stl

description.text:
1" Scale miniature stand for your D&D miniature figs. Fits standard 1" round miniature bases, and has room for 16 figs. The pillars on the corners also interlock into slots on the bottom of the floor so you can stack as many as you'd like to make a multi-level dungeon-style shelf! Great for storing and displaying your miniatures. -- Several resources I used in making this: Wall elements from "OpenForge Ruined Wall Tile"
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:526706 Floor cobblestones from "Cobblestone road for tabletop war games"
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:126575

Just a quick note:  
Since this is kind of wide and flat (total of 6" x 6", perfect for a Printrbot Simple), you might want to take precautions to prevent edge warping. If the corners curl up too much, the floors won't stack perfectly.  
After a few test prints, I got the best results by printing at 400 micron, with 2 layer walls/floors and 20% infill. Just make sure your base is nice and clean so you get good adhesion.

title: Centuri Alien Scoutship #5325 Model Rocket Embossing Templates

description.text: These are embossing templates for recreating the embossed cardstock shrouds for this classic Centuri model rocket kit.  It's not parts for building the rocket itself but rather tools for making the parts.  Using regular cardstock and readily available embossing tools from a craft store you can make your own parts!

These tools will help you recreate the parts for the kit but you will need other things as well. You should download the original instructions from: http://www.spacemodeling.org/jimz/cen5325.htm You will also need:
  • Embossing tool(s) such as those made by McGill but any stick with a smooth 1/16" rounded end should work
  • Cardstock, preferably with a smooth, shiny clay coating
  • Medium weight chipboard
  • Piano wire to make the landing struts
  • BT20 motor tube
  • BT20 engine block
  • 18mm motor retainer
  • 1/8" launch lug
    • It's also helpful if you have a craft circle cutting tool for cutting out the shrouds for accuracy. You must refer to the original instructions for assembly but here are some tips for using the templates. The cardstock should be placed in the template face down. If you have clay finished cardstock this is the outer face. It takes paint better. Use an embossing tool to trace the outline of each feature. You need to press firmly but not too hard as to slip or tear the card stock. Practice with scraps to get the hand of it. The main shroud is in 6 pieces. Refer to the instruction drawings for the layout of each one. The same for the core tube template which has a repeated pattern. The minor shroud template is used my embossing a section, sliding the cardstock to work on the next section but overlapping a stripe to help register the pattern. If you use unfinished cardstock or chipboard for the parts it is recommended to use a couple of coats of sanding sealer and priming prior to assembly. It will make painting easier later. Also included are a PDF for decals and a 2D drawing of the base plate part in case you have access to a laser cutter.

This is a mount for protecting the bare pcb and lenses of the Nerdcam 3d. The mount provides for four 2mm screws at the stock mounting locations. The screws will self thread into the plastic, with a little pressure (even machine screws). It also has enough room behind the pcb when mounted to connect any wires or add any additional pins you may need. Also there is a generous pass through hole in the bottom center for wiring. The coverbase, covers the pcb and the lens housings. And the covertop provides protection to the lenses and adds a little bling. The covertop and coverbase are meant to be glued together, or you can just leave the covertop off altogether to save a little weight. Update 3-1-2015 Added Nerdcamwholecover.stl for those brave enough to try and print it with supports, or if you have a hips capable printer.

The mount was made with two shells and 25% infill, as was the coverbase. The covertop was 2 shells and 15% infill. All models were scaled up 1.01 (in x and y only) to account for ABS shrinking on my printer. Adjust as necessary for your printer and material choice.

title: Legend of Zelda: Windwaker - Prince Komali

description.text:
I'm going through Legend of Zelda: Windwaker and realizing that I really want miniatures of all the notable characters.
Number 5: Prince Komali. Put a little marble or something in his hands for Din's Pearl.
He's also lying down the first time you see him, so I thought I'd prepare that pose, too. If it's not blatantly obvious, I'll say it, use supports! Dissolvable supports produce a better result if your printer can do it. If you like it, let me know! Click the button shaped like a heart.
And perhaps, you know, if you've got a sec, you could... you know... throw a comment my way. Makes me feel good. Everything about this belongs to Nintendo.

If you plan on printing him, use supports. Dissolvable works best, if you have more than one extruder.  
If you like, print him large enough that you can put a marble or something in his hands for Din's Pearl.  
Then paint, if you fancy.

The first time I played Windwaker, I immediately fell in love with it. Playing the game literally felt like being able to interface with a work of captivating art. The visuals were (still are) stunning, the music, eloquent, and the characters, memorable, and their personalities well textured.
I loved them all. But I particularly had an eye for one, more so. So... I've been playing Windwaker over again recently, and I wanted miniatures of all the important/recurring characters.
This is the 7th one I've prepared, Medli, and she's my favorite. Her design, her development, her story, I love this little Rito. This /may/ be reflected in the fact that I've prepared 8 poses for her. Enjoy~ Everything about this belongs to Nintendo. And thank you, Eiji Aonuma, Yoshiaki Koizumi, Yoshiyuki Oyama, and of course Shigeru Miyamoto (though I realize none of you may ever even read this) for giving me this work of art game to begin with.

Print with supports, whichever pose you plan to print.  
Paint if you like.

To anyone who is going to put this print through, scale her just a bit wider for her hands together model. I'll fix the actual model when I have some time, but until then, if you're gonna put this print through, she needs to be scaled, like, a few mm wider to get her proportions correct.

title: Chess Set I
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Traditional (Staunton-style) chess set. The knight is a draft piece that I hope to revisit -- getting a recognizable horse-bust without exceeding the maximum overhang angles is hard. Please note: my printer isn\'t here yet, so while I have sliced these models and inspected the tool paths that result, I haven\'t verified that they print properly on actual hardware. I would love feedback from any chess fans with printers! :-)

All pieces so far print ready-to-use except the King, who traditionally has a cross on his crown.  The cross prints beside him, and should be glued in place (divot provided).
Note that the pieces are mathematically lathed, and the perimeter loops have a large number of vertices.  This is a recipe for trouble if your printer slows down on high-detail areas.  For a MakerBot, I've had good results by printing from SD card, and very bad results over serial.

Edit: After printing "LG_STAND.STL", I realized vertical resolution makes the upper half quite ugly. I now recommend printing the second part with supports upright. I've included my .gcode file for "Just_The_G3.STL" with support uploaded the new STLs.  
The file "LG_STAND.STL" is old and not recommended for printing.

Voici un mod pour la K8200 qui permet avec les pièces d'origines de changer le fonctionnement de la machine, ce mod permet de faire bouger la tête d'impression plutôt que la table. Les dimensions mesurées sont : X : 300mm
Y : 245mm
Z : 220mm Ce qui vous permet d'imaginer pas mal de chose ;-) je join aussi le firmware Marlin déjà modifié pour la bête. J'attends vos impressions et remarques, merci d'avance.

Voici le BOM : à commander :
16x roulements F605Z
2x poulies GT2 2mm
4m de courroie GT2 2mm
2x tige fileté 500mm
2x tige fileté 325mm pour le montage : Assembler comme sur les images, les 2 tiges fileté de 325mm sont des renforts du chariot Y. Les 2 tiges fileté 500mm sont des renforts du chassi. Voilà j'espère que ça plaira.

description.text: This rack is great for keeping your CNC collets handy. This was my first project with a ShopBot Desktop CNC Router, but you could also 3D-print this.

You can 3D printer this rack or make it with a CNC router. I made mine out of a thick pine board, using this project as my first learning experience with a ShopBot Desktop CNC router. I used 3 different tools/bits, with 3 total tool changes, in making it:  
First, I cut the inside pockets and the top half of the perimeter cut with a 1/4" flat endmill.  
Then I drilled the mounting holes (centered in 4 of the collet holes) with a #30 drill. During the tool change, I screwed down the part with pan-head wood screws through the #30 holes I just drilled.  
Next I changed to an1/8" roundover mill to smooth the edges.  
Finally, I changed back to the 1/4" flat endmill to finish the bottom half of the perimeter cut.  
Good luck!
